Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration: This project provides travel support for 10-15 students attending the 2016 Annual Computer Security Applications Conference (ACSAC). ACSAC, which is celebrating its 32nd year, is a top-tier academic security conference that attracts averages about 250-300 highly skilled security professionals and student attendees per year. ACSAC has carved a unique role as a security conference equally attended by academia, industry, and government. In addition to the technical papers, the conference program will include keynotes by distinguished speakers, tutorials, case studies, panels, a poster session, and works-in-progress talks. This project will help to groom the next generation of cybersecurity professionals by facilitating interaction of students with experts in the field.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Annual Computer Security Applications Conference (ACSAC) is a top-tier academic security conference whose core mission is investigating practical solutions for computer security technology. Run by the Applied Computer Security Associates (ACSA), it brings together the foremost minds in academia, industry, and government to address the most pressing problems in applied computer security, as well as discuss seminal works in information security. ACSAC is a highly competitive, peer-reviewed conference. The conference program is comprised of two days of tutorials and workshops, and three days of keynote talks, panels, a “works-in-progress” or WIP session, a poster session, and technical paper sessions. 

The ACSAC 2016 Student Support project provided NSF and supplemental DHS funds for ACSAC 2016, which was held in Los Angeles, CA on December 5-9, 2016. The project also provided supplemental DHS funds for ACSAC 2017, which was held in Orlando, FL on December 4-8. 2017.

NSF and DHS funds supported students from: U.S. educational institutions; recipients of Scholarships for Women Studying Information Security (SWSIS), which provides assistance to women studying for their Bachelors or Masters degrees in fields relating to information security; and students participating in the pre-conference TracerFIRE training class, a forensic and incident response program developed by Sandia and Los Alamos National Laboratories. Separate ACSA funding supported students from foreign institutions. All other students attending the conference and/or pre-conference workshops or tutorials received discounted registration fees paid by ACSAC from general registration fees.

The attached table provides statistics on overall ACSAC 2016 and ACSAC 2017  attendance, technical papers, and supported students, including degrees pursued, active roles in the conference, women, and underrepresented minorities.

ACSAC 2016 offered 6 professional development classes or tutorials during the first two days of its weeklong program. DHS funds supported travel costs for instructors for 2 of the tutorials: Hands-On Interactive Car Hacking and Advancing Next Generation Research into Binary Analysis.

ACSAC 2017 featured 2 keynote talks and DHS funds supported conference fees and travel costs for the keynote speakers: Raffael Marty, VP Security Analytics, Sophos, Distinguished Practitioner Keynote: Delivering Security Insights with Data Analytics and Visualization; and Christian Collberg, Professor of Computer Science, University of Arizona, Invited Essayist Keynote: Dare to Share: Risks and Rewards of Artifact Sharing in Computer Science.

A key goal of the ACSAC 2016 Student Support project was to provide opportunities for student education, as well as training and professional development. Students participating in the conferences gained valuable insight into current research. A number of students shared their research with other conference participants by presenting papers, WIPs, and posters. Attendees learned from the students and made connections that could lead to future employment. TracerFIRE provided student attendees a unique opportunity to learn key forensic and incident response skills, and to improve collaboration and teamwork. The invited keynote speeches gave conference attendees leading experts’ perspective on applying security to difficult technical problems. Similarly, the tutorials offered attendees a diverse set of classes in key topics areas.

The ACSAC conference is widely publicized and open to all members of the international information security community. The conference proceedings were published by the Association for Computing Machinery (ACM) and are available via the ACM Digital Library. The Proceedings were made freely available to all conference attendees electronically via the ACSAC web site.

ACSAC greatly appreciates NSF and DHS support. The conference helps feed the development of new computer and network security technologies and their application to solve address critical security, resilience, and privacy challenges in today’s information security systems. By promoting and supporting student participation, tutorial instructors, and keynote speakers, the conference facilitates education and interaction and helps develop and groom the next generation of security professionals.
